-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newUpdateStackSet</a> smart constructor.
data UpdateStackSet
UpdateStackSet' :: Maybe PermissionModels -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [Capability] -> Maybe DeploymentTargets -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe CallAs -> Maybe StackSetOperationPreferences -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [Tag] -> Maybe AutoDeployment -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [Parameter] -> Maybe Bool -> Text -> UpdateStackSet

-- | Create a value of <a>UpdateStackSet</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:permissionModel:UpdateStackSet'</a>,
--   <a>updateStackSet_permissionModel</a> - Describes how the IAM roles
--   required for stack set operations are created. You cannot modify
--   <tt>PermissionModel</tt> if there are stack instances associated with
--   your stack set.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>With <tt>self-managed</tt> permissions, you must create the
--   administrator and execution roles required to deploy to target
--   accounts. For more information, see <a>Grant Self-Managed Stack Set
--   Permissions</a>.</li>
--   <li>With <tt>service-managed</tt> permissions, StackSets automatically
--   creates the IAM roles required to deploy to accounts managed by
--   Organizations. For more information, see <a>Grant Service-Managed
--   Stack Set Permissions</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:executionRoleName:UpdateStackSet'</a>,
--   <a>updateStackSet_executionRoleName</a> - The name of the IAM
--   execution role to use to update the stack set. If you do not specify
--   an execution role, CloudFormation uses the
--   <tt>AWSCloudFormationStackSetExecutionRole</tt> role for the stack set
--   operation.
--   
--   Specify an IAM role only if you are using customized execution roles
--   to control which stack resources users and groups can include in their
--   stack sets.
--   
--   If you specify a customized execution role, CloudFormation uses that
--   role to update the stack. If you do not specify a customized execution
--   role, CloudFormation performs the update using the role previously
--   associated with the stack set, so long as you have permissions to
--   perform operations on the stack set.
--   
--   <a>$sel:capabilities:UpdateStackSet'</a>,
--   <a>updateStackSet_capabilities</a> - In some cases, you must
--   explicitly acknowledge that your stack template contains certain
--   capabilities in order for CloudFormation to update the stack set and
--   its associated stack instances.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>CAPABILITY_IAM</tt> and <tt>CAPABILITY_NAMED_IAM</tt>Some
--   stack templates might include resources that can affect permissions in
--   your Amazon Web Services account; for example, by creating new
--   Identity and Access Management (IAM) users. For those stacks sets, you
--   must explicitly acknowledge this by specifying one of these
--   capabilities.The following IAM resources require you to specify either
--   the <tt>CAPABILITY_IAM</tt> or <tt>CAPABILITY_NAMED_IAM</tt>
--   capability.<ul><li>If you have IAM resources, you can specify either
--   capability.</li><li>If you have IAM resources with custom names, you
--   <i>must</i> specify <tt>CAPABILITY_NAMED_IAM</tt>.</li><li>If you
--   don't specify either of these capabilities, CloudFormation returns an
--   <tt>InsufficientCapabilities</tt> error.</li></ul>If your stack
--   template contains these resources, we recommend that you review all
--   permissions associated with them and edit their permissions if
--   necessary.<ul><li><a>AWS::IAM::AccessKey</a></li><li><a>AWS::IAM::Group</a></li><li><a>AWS::IAM::InstanceProfile</a></li><li><a>AWS::IAM::Policy</a></li><li><a>AWS::IAM::Role</a></li><li><a>AWS::IAM::User</a></li><li><a>AWS::IAM::UserToGroupAddition</a></li></ul>For
--   more information, see <a>Acknowledging IAM Resources in CloudFormation
--   Templates</a>.</li>
--   <li><pre>CAPABILITY_AUTO_EXPAND</pre>Some templates reference macros.
--   If your stack set template references one or more macros, you must
--   update the stack set directly from the processed template, without
--   first reviewing the resulting changes in a change set. To update the
--   stack set directly, you must acknowledge this capability. For more
--   information, see <a>Using CloudFormation Macros to Perform Custom
--   Processing on Templates</a>.Stack sets with service-managed
--   permissions do not currently support the use of macros in templates.
--   (This includes the <a>AWS::Include</a> and <a>AWS::Serverless</a>
--   transforms, which are macros hosted by CloudFormation.) Even if you
--   specify this capability for a stack set with service-managed
--   permissions, if you reference a macro in your template the stack set
--   operation will fail.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:deploymentTargets:UpdateStackSet'</a>,
--   <a>updateStackSet_deploymentTargets</a> - [Service-managed
--   permissions] The Organizations accounts in which to update associated
--   stack instances.
--   
--   To update all the stack instances associated with this stack set, do
--   not specify <tt>DeploymentTargets</tt> or <tt>Regions</tt>.
--   
--   If the stack set update includes changes to the template (that is, if
--   <tt>TemplateBody</tt> or <tt>TemplateURL</tt> is specified), or the
--   <tt>Parameters</tt>, CloudFormation marks all stack instances with a
--   status of <tt>OUTDATED</tt> prior to updating the stack instances in
--   the specified accounts and Regions. If the stack set update does not
--   include changes to the template or parameters, CloudFormation updates
--   the stack instances in the specified accounts and Regions, while
--   leaving all other stack instances with their existing stack instance
--   status.
--   
--   <a>$sel:templateURL:UpdateStackSet'</a>,
--   <a>updateStackSet_templateURL</a> - The location of the file that
--   contains the template body. The URL must point to a template (maximum
--   size: 460,800 bytes) that is located in an Amazon S3 bucket or a
--   Systems Manager document. For more information, see <a>Template
--   Anatomy</a> in the CloudFormation User Guide.
--   
--   Conditional: You must specify only one of the following parameters:
--   <tt>TemplateBody</tt> or <tt>TemplateURL</tt>—or set
--   <tt>UsePreviousTemplate</tt> to true.
--   
--   <a>$sel:operationId:UpdateStackSet'</a>,
--   <a>updateStackSet_operationId</a> - The unique ID for this stack set
--   operation.
--   
--   The operation ID also functions as an idempotency token, to ensure
--   that CloudFormation performs the stack set operation only once, even
--   if you retry the request multiple times. You might retry stack set
--   operation requests to ensure that CloudFormation successfully received
--   them.
--   
--   If you don't specify an operation ID, CloudFormation generates one
--   automatically.
--   
--   Repeating this stack set operation with a new operation ID retries all
--   stack instances whose status is <tt>OUTDATED</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:callAs:UpdateStackSet'</a>, <a>updateStackSet_callAs</a> -
--   [Service-managed permissions] Specifies whether you are acting as an
--   account administrator in the organization's management account or as a
--   delegated administrator in a member account.
--   
--   By default, <tt>SELF</tt> is specified. Use <tt>SELF</tt> for stack
--   sets with self-managed permissions.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>If you are signed in to the management account, specify
--   <tt>SELF</tt>.</li>
--   <li>If you are signed in to a delegated administrator account, specify
--   <tt>DELEGATED_ADMIN</tt>.Your Amazon Web Services account must be
--   registered as a delegated administrator in the management account. For
--   more information, see <a>Register a delegated administrator</a> in the
--   <i>CloudFormation User Guide</i>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:operationPreferences:UpdateStackSet'</a>,
--   <a>updateStackSet_operationPreferences</a> - Preferences for how
--   CloudFormation performs this stack set operation.
--   
--   <a>$sel:accounts:UpdateStackSet'</a>, <a>updateStackSet_accounts</a> -
--   [Self-managed permissions] The accounts in which to update associated
--   stack instances. If you specify accounts, you must also specify the
--   Regions in which to update stack set instances.
--   
--   To update <i>all</i> the stack instances associated with this stack
--   set, do not specify the <tt>Accounts</tt> or <tt>Regions</tt>
--   properties.
--   
--   If the stack set update includes changes to the template (that is, if
--   the <tt>TemplateBody</tt> or <tt>TemplateURL</tt> properties are
--   specified), or the <tt>Parameters</tt> property, CloudFormation marks
--   all stack instances with a status of <tt>OUTDATED</tt> prior to
--   updating the stack instances in the specified accounts and Regions. If
--   the stack set update does not include changes to the template or
--   parameters, CloudFormation updates the stack instances in the
--   specified accounts and Regions, while leaving all other stack
--   instances with their existing stack instance status.
--   
--   <a>$sel:administrationRoleARN:UpdateStackSet'</a>,
--   <a>updateStackSet_administrationRoleARN</a> - The Amazon Resource
--   Number (ARN) of the IAM role to use to update this stack set.
--   
--   Specify an IAM role only if you are using customized administrator
--   roles to control which users or groups can manage specific stack sets
--   within the same administrator account. For more information, see
--   <a>Granting Permissions for Stack Set Operations</a> in the
--   <i>CloudFormation User Guide</i>.
--   
--   If you specified a customized administrator role when you created the
--   stack set, you must specify a customized administrator role, even if
--   it is the same customized administrator role used with this stack set
--   previously.
--   
--   <a>$sel:tags:UpdateStackSet'</a>, <a>updateStackSet_tags</a> - The
--   key-value pairs to associate with this stack set and the stacks
--   created from it. CloudFormation also propagates these tags to
--   supported resources that are created in the stacks. You can specify a
--   maximum number of 50 tags.
--   
--   If you specify tags for this parameter, those tags replace any list of
--   tags that are currently associated with this stack set. This means:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>If you don't specify this parameter, CloudFormation doesn't modify
--   the stack's tags.</li>
--   <li>If you specify <i>any</i> tags using this parameter, you must
--   specify <i>all</i> the tags that you want associated with this stack
--   set, even tags you've specifed before (for example, when creating the
--   stack set or during a previous update of the stack set.). Any tags
--   that you don't include in the updated list of tags are removed from
--   the stack set, and therefore from the stacks and resources as
--   well.</li>
--   <li>If you specify an empty value, CloudFormation removes all
--   currently associated tags.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   If you specify new tags as part of an <tt>UpdateStackSet</tt> action,
--   CloudFormation checks to see if you have the required IAM permission
--   to tag resources. If you omit tags that are currently associated with
--   the stack set from the list of tags you specify, CloudFormation
--   assumes that you want to remove those tags from the stack set, and
--   checks to see if you have permission to untag resources. If you don't
--   have the necessary permission(s), the entire <tt>UpdateStackSet</tt>
--   action fails with an <tt>access denied</tt> error, and the stack set
--   is not updated.
--   
--   <a>$sel:autoDeployment:UpdateStackSet'</a>,
--   <a>updateStackSet_autoDeployment</a> - [Service-managed permissions]
--   Describes whether StackSets automatically deploys to Organizations
--   accounts that are added to a target organization or organizational
--   unit (OU).
--   
--   If you specify <tt>AutoDeployment</tt>, do not specify
--   <tt>DeploymentTargets</tt> or <tt>Regions</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:description:UpdateStackSet'</a>,
--   <a>updateStackSet_description</a> - A brief description of updates
--   that you are making.
--   
--   <a>$sel:regions:UpdateStackSet'</a>, <a>updateStackSet_regions</a> -
--   The Regions in which to update associated stack instances. If you
--   specify Regions, you must also specify accounts in which to update
--   stack set instances.
--   
--   To update <i>all</i> the stack instances associated with this stack
--   set, do not specify the <tt>Accounts</tt> or <tt>Regions</tt>
--   properties.
--   
--   If the stack set update includes changes to the template (that is, if
--   the <tt>TemplateBody</tt> or <tt>TemplateURL</tt> properties are
--   specified), or the <tt>Parameters</tt> property, CloudFormation marks
--   all stack instances with a status of <tt>OUTDATED</tt> prior to
--   updating the stack instances in the specified accounts and Regions. If
--   the stack set update does not include changes to the template or
--   parameters, CloudFormation updates the stack instances in the
--   specified accounts and Regions, while leaving all other stack
--   instances with their existing stack instance status.
--   
--   <a>$sel:templateBody:UpdateStackSet'</a>,
--   <a>updateStackSet_templateBody</a> - The structure that contains the
--   template body, with a minimum length of 1 byte and a maximum length of
--   51,200 bytes. For more information, see <a>Template Anatomy</a> in the
--   CloudFormation User Guide.
--   
--   Conditional: You must specify only one of the following parameters:
--   <tt>TemplateBody</tt> or <tt>TemplateURL</tt>—or set
--   <tt>UsePreviousTemplate</tt> to true.
--   
--   <a>$sel:parameters:UpdateStackSet'</a>,
--   <a>updateStackSet_parameters</a> - A list of input parameters for the
--   stack set template.
--   
--   <a>$sel:usePreviousTemplate:UpdateStackSet'</a>,
--   <a>updateStackSet_usePreviousTemplate</a> - Use the existing template
--   that's associated with the stack set that you're updating.
--   
--   Conditional: You must specify only one of the following parameters:
--   <tt>TemplateBody</tt> or <tt>TemplateURL</tt>—or set
--   <tt>UsePreviousTemplate</tt> to true.
--   
--   <a>$sel:stackSetName:UpdateStackSet'</a>,
--   <a>updateStackSet_stackSetName</a> - The name or unique ID of the
--   stack set that you want to update.
newUpdateStackSet :: Text -> UpdateStackSet

-- | The input for CreateStack action.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newCreateStack</a> smart constructor.
data CreateStack
CreateStack' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe OnFailure -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [Capability] -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [Tag] -> Maybe Natural -> Maybe RollbackConfiguration -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe [Parameter] -> Text -> CreateStack

-- | Create a value of <a>CreateStack</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:roleARN:CreateStack'</a>, <a>createStack_roleARN</a> - The
--   Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of an Identity and Access Management (IAM)
--   role that CloudFormation assumes to create the stack. CloudFormation
--   uses the role's credentials to make calls on your behalf.
--   CloudFormation always uses this role for all future operations on the
--   stack. As long as users have permission to operate on the stack,
--   CloudFormation uses this role even if the users don't have permission
--   to pass it. Ensure that the role grants least privilege.
--   
--   If you don't specify a value, CloudFormation uses the role that was
--   previously associated with the stack. If no role is available,
--   CloudFormation uses a temporary session that is generated from your
--   user credentials.
--   
--   <a>$sel:onFailure:CreateStack'</a>, <a>createStack_onFailure</a> -
--   Determines what action will be taken if stack creation fails. This
--   must be one of: DO_NOTHING, ROLLBACK, or DELETE. You can specify
--   either <tt>OnFailure</tt> or <tt>DisableRollback</tt>, but not both.
--   
--   Default: <tt>ROLLBACK</tt>
--   
--   <a>$sel:resourceTypes:CreateStack'</a>,
--   <a>createStack_resourceTypes</a> - The template resource types that
--   you have permissions to work with for this create stack action, such
--   as <tt>AWS::EC2::Instance</tt>, <tt>AWS::EC2::*</tt>, or
--   <tt>Custom::MyCustomInstance</tt>. Use the following syntax to
--   describe template resource types: <tt>AWS::*</tt> (for all Amazon Web
--   Services resources), <tt>Custom::*</tt> (for all custom resources),
--   <tt>Custom::logical_ID </tt> (for a specific custom resource),
--   <tt>AWS::service_name::*</tt> (for all resources of a particular
--   Amazon Web Services service), and
--   <tt>AWS::service_name::resource_logical_ID </tt> (for a specific
--   Amazon Web Services resource).
--   
--   If the list of resource types doesn't include a resource that you're
--   creating, the stack creation fails. By default, CloudFormation grants
--   permissions to all resource types. Identity and Access Management
--   (IAM) uses this parameter for CloudFormation-specific condition keys
--   in IAM policies. For more information, see <a>Controlling Access with
--   Identity and Access Management</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:enableTerminationProtection:CreateStack'</a>,
--   <a>createStack_enableTerminationProtection</a> - Whether to enable
--   termination protection on the specified stack. If a user attempts to
--   delete a stack with termination protection enabled, the operation
--   fails and the stack remains unchanged. For more information, see
--   <a>Protecting a Stack From Being Deleted</a> in the <i>CloudFormation
--   User Guide</i>. Termination protection is disabled on stacks by
--   default.
--   
--   For <a>nested stacks</a>, termination protection is set on the root
--   stack and cannot be changed directly on the nested stack.
--   
--   <a>$sel:stackPolicyBody:CreateStack'</a>,
--   <a>createStack_stackPolicyBody</a> - Structure containing the stack
--   policy body. For more information, go to <a>Prevent Updates to Stack
--   Resources</a> in the <i>CloudFormation User Guide</i>. You can specify
--   either the <tt>StackPolicyBody</tt> or the <tt>StackPolicyURL</tt>
--   parameter, but not both.
--   
--   <a>$sel:capabilities:CreateStack'</a>, <a>createStack_capabilities</a>
--   - In some cases, you must explicitly acknowledge that your stack
--   template contains certain capabilities in order for CloudFormation to
--   create the stack.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>CAPABILITY_IAM</tt> and <tt>CAPABILITY_NAMED_IAM</tt>Some
--   stack templates might include resources that can affect permissions in
--   your Amazon Web Services account; for example, by creating new
--   Identity and Access Management (IAM) users. For those stacks, you must
--   explicitly acknowledge this by specifying one of these
--   capabilities.The following IAM resources require you to specify either
--   the <tt>CAPABILITY_IAM</tt> or <tt>CAPABILITY_NAMED_IAM</tt>
--   capability.<ul><li>If you have IAM resources, you can specify either
--   capability.</li><li>If you have IAM resources with custom names, you
--   <i>must</i> specify <tt>CAPABILITY_NAMED_IAM</tt>.</li><li>If you
--   don't specify either of these capabilities, CloudFormation returns an
--   <tt>InsufficientCapabilities</tt> error.</li></ul>If your stack
--   template contains these resources, we recommend that you review all
--   permissions associated with them and edit their permissions if
--   necessary.<ul><li><a>AWS::IAM::AccessKey</a></li><li><a>AWS::IAM::Group</a></li><li><a>AWS::IAM::InstanceProfile</a></li><li><a>AWS::IAM::Policy</a></li><li><a>AWS::IAM::Role</a></li><li><a>AWS::IAM::User</a></li><li><a>AWS::IAM::UserToGroupAddition</a></li></ul>For
--   more information, see <a>Acknowledging IAM Resources in CloudFormation
--   Templates</a>.</li>
--   <li><pre>CAPABILITY_AUTO_EXPAND</pre>Some template contain macros.
--   Macros perform custom processing on templates; this can include simple
--   actions like find-and-replace operations, all the way to extensive
--   transformations of entire templates. Because of this, users typically
--   create a change set from the processed template, so that they can
--   review the changes resulting from the macros before actually creating
--   the stack. If your stack template contains one or more macros, and you
--   choose to create a stack directly from the processed template, without
--   first reviewing the resulting changes in a change set, you must
--   acknowledge this capability. This includes the <a>AWS::Include</a> and
--   <a>AWS::Serverless</a> transforms, which are macros hosted by
--   CloudFormation.If you want to create a stack from a stack template
--   that contains macros <i>and</i> nested stacks, you must create the
--   stack directly from the template using this capability.You should only
--   create stacks directly from a stack template that contains macros if
--   you know what processing the macro performs.Each macro relies on an
--   underlying Lambda service function for processing stack templates. Be
--   aware that the Lambda function owner can update the function operation
--   without CloudFormation being notified.For more information, see
--   <a>Using CloudFormation Macros to Perform Custom Processing on
--   Templates</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:notificationARNs:CreateStack'</a>,
--   <a>createStack_notificationARNs</a> - The Simple Notification Service
--   (SNS) topic ARNs to publish stack related events. You can find your
--   SNS topic ARNs using the SNS console or your Command Line Interface
--   (CLI).
--   
--   <a>$sel:templateURL:CreateStack'</a>, <a>createStack_templateURL</a> -
--   Location of file containing the template body. The URL must point to a
--   template (max size: 460,800 bytes) that is located in an Amazon S3
--   bucket or a Systems Manager document. For more information, go to the
--   <a>Template Anatomy</a> in the CloudFormation User Guide.
--   
--   Conditional: You must specify either the <tt>TemplateBody</tt> or the
--   <tt>TemplateURL</tt> parameter, but not both.
--   
--   <a>$sel:stackPolicyURL:CreateStack'</a>,
--   <a>createStack_stackPolicyURL</a> - Location of a file containing the
--   stack policy. The URL must point to a policy (maximum size: 16 KB)
--   located in an S3 bucket in the same Region as the stack. You can
--   specify either the <tt>StackPolicyBody</tt> or the
--   <tt>StackPolicyURL</tt> parameter, but not both.
--   
--   <a>$sel:tags:CreateStack'</a>, <a>createStack_tags</a> - Key-value
--   pairs to associate with this stack. CloudFormation also propagates
--   these tags to the resources created in the stack. A maximum number of
--   50 tags can be specified.
--   
--   <a>$sel:timeoutInMinutes:CreateStack'</a>,
--   <a>createStack_timeoutInMinutes</a> - The amount of time that can pass
--   before the stack status becomes CREATE_FAILED; if
--   <tt>DisableRollback</tt> is not set or is set to <tt>false</tt>, the
--   stack will be rolled back.
--   
--   <a>$sel:rollbackConfiguration:CreateStack'</a>,
--   <a>createStack_rollbackConfiguration</a> - The rollback triggers for
--   CloudFormation to monitor during stack creation and updating
--   operations, and for the specified monitoring period afterwards.
--   
--   <a>$sel:clientRequestToken:CreateStack'</a>,
--   <a>createStack_clientRequestToken</a> - A unique identifier for this
--   <tt>CreateStack</tt> request. Specify this token if you plan to retry
--   requests so that CloudFormation knows that you're not attempting to
--   create a stack with the same name. You might retry
--   <tt>CreateStack</tt> requests to ensure that CloudFormation
--   successfully received them.
--   
--   All events triggered by a given stack operation are assigned the same
--   client request token, which you can use to track operations. For
--   example, if you execute a <tt>CreateStack</tt> operation with the
--   token <tt>token1</tt>, then all the <tt>StackEvents</tt> generated by
--   that operation will have <tt>ClientRequestToken</tt> set as
--   <tt>token1</tt>.
--   
--   In the console, stack operations display the client request token on
--   the Events tab. Stack operations that are initiated from the console
--   use the token format <i>Console-StackOperation-ID</i>, which helps you
--   easily identify the stack operation . For example, if you create a
--   stack using the console, each stack event would be assigned the same
--   token in the following format:
--   <tt>Console-CreateStack-7f59c3cf-00d2-40c7-b2ff-e75db0987002</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:templateBody:CreateStack'</a>, <a>createStack_templateBody</a>
--   - Structure containing the template body with a minimum length of 1
--   byte and a maximum length of 51,200 bytes. For more information, go to
--   <a>Template Anatomy</a> in the CloudFormation User Guide.
--   
--   Conditional: You must specify either the <tt>TemplateBody</tt> or the
--   <tt>TemplateURL</tt> parameter, but not both.
--   
--   <a>$sel:disableRollback:CreateStack'</a>,
--   <a>createStack_disableRollback</a> - Set to <tt>true</tt> to disable
--   rollback of the stack if stack creation failed. You can specify either
--   <tt>DisableRollback</tt> or <tt>OnFailure</tt>, but not both.
--   
--   Default: <tt>false</tt>
--   
--   <a>$sel:parameters:CreateStack'</a>, <a>createStack_parameters</a> - A
--   list of <tt>Parameter</tt> structures that specify input parameters
--   for the stack. For more information, see the <a>Parameter</a> data
--   type.
--   
--   <a>$sel:stackName:CreateStack'</a>, <a>createStack_stackName</a> - The
--   name that is associated with the stack. The name must be unique in the
--   Region in which you are creating the stack.
--   
--   A stack name can contain only alphanumeric characters (case sensitive)
--   and hyphens. It must start with an alphabetical character and cannot
--   be longer than 128 characters.
newCreateStack :: Text -> CreateStack

data GetTemplateSummaryResponse
GetTemplateSummaryResponse' :: Maybe [Text] -> Maybe [Capability] -> Maybe [ResourceIdentifierSummary] -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [ParameterDeclaration] -> Maybe Text -> Int -> GetTemplateSummaryResponse

-- | Create a value of <a>GetTemplateSummaryResponse</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:resourceTypes:GetTemplateSummaryResponse'</a>,
--   <a>getTemplateSummaryResponse_resourceTypes</a> - A list of all the
--   template resource types that are defined in the template, such as
--   <tt>AWS::EC2::Instance</tt>, <tt>AWS::Dynamo::Table</tt>, and
--   <tt>Custom::MyCustomInstance</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:capabilities:GetTemplateSummaryResponse'</a>,
--   <a>getTemplateSummaryResponse_capabilities</a> - The capabilities
--   found within the template. If your template contains IAM resources,
--   you must specify the <tt>CAPABILITY_IAM</tt> or
--   <tt>CAPABILITY_NAMED_IAM</tt> value for this parameter when you use
--   the CreateStack or UpdateStack actions with your template; otherwise,
--   those actions return an <tt>InsufficientCapabilities</tt> error.
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Acknowledging IAM Resources in
--   CloudFormation Templates</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:resourceIdentifierSummaries:GetTemplateSummaryResponse'</a>,
--   <a>getTemplateSummaryResponse_resourceIdentifierSummaries</a> - A list
--   of resource identifier summaries that describe the target resources of
--   an import operation and the properties you can provide during the
--   import to identify the target resources. For example,
--   <tt>BucketName</tt> is a possible identifier property for an
--   <tt>AWS::S3::Bucket</tt> resource.
--   
--   <a>$sel:declaredTransforms:GetTemplateSummaryResponse'</a>,
--   <a>getTemplateSummaryResponse_declaredTransforms</a> - A list of the
--   transforms that are declared in the template.
--   
--   <a>$sel:metadata:GetTemplateSummaryResponse'</a>,
--   <a>getTemplateSummaryResponse_metadata</a> - The value that is defined
--   for the <tt>Metadata</tt> property of the template.
--   
--   <a>$sel:version:GetTemplateSummaryResponse'</a>,
--   <a>getTemplateSummaryResponse_version</a> - The Amazon Web Services
--   template format version, which identifies the capabilities of the
--   template.
--   
--   <a>$sel:description:GetTemplateSummaryResponse'</a>,
--   <a>getTemplateSummaryResponse_description</a> - The value that is
--   defined in the <tt>Description</tt> property of the template.
--   
--   <a>$sel:parameters:GetTemplateSummaryResponse'</a>,
--   <a>getTemplateSummaryResponse_parameters</a> - A list of parameter
--   declarations that describe various properties for each parameter.
--   
--   <a>$sel:capabilitiesReason:GetTemplateSummaryResponse'</a>,
--   <a>getTemplateSummaryResponse_capabilitiesReason</a> - The list of
--   resources that generated the values in the <tt>Capabilities</tt>
--   response element.
--   
--   <a>$sel:httpStatus:GetTemplateSummaryResponse'</a>,
--   <a>getTemplateSummaryResponse_httpStatus</a> - The response's http
--   status code.
newGetTemplateSummaryResponse :: Int -> GetTemplateSummaryResponse

data DeleteStack
DeleteStack' :: Maybe [Text] -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Text -> DeleteStack

-- | Create a value of <a>DeleteStack</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:retainResources:DeleteStack'</a>,
--   <a>deleteStack_retainResources</a> - For stacks in the
--   <tt>DELETE_FAILED</tt> state, a list of resource logical IDs that are
--   associated with the resources you want to retain. During deletion,
--   CloudFormation deletes the stack but does not delete the retained
--   resources.
--   
--   Retaining resources is useful when you cannot delete a resource, such
--   as a non-empty S3 bucket, but you want to delete the stack.
--   
--   <a>$sel:roleARN:DeleteStack'</a>, <a>deleteStack_roleARN</a> - The
--   Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of an Identity and Access Management (IAM)
--   role that CloudFormation assumes to delete the stack. CloudFormation
--   uses the role's credentials to make calls on your behalf.
--   
--   If you don't specify a value, CloudFormation uses the role that was
--   previously associated with the stack. If no role is available,
--   CloudFormation uses a temporary session that is generated from your
--   user credentials.
--   
--   <a>$sel:clientRequestToken:DeleteStack'</a>,
--   <a>deleteStack_clientRequestToken</a> - A unique identifier for this
--   <tt>DeleteStack</tt> request. Specify this token if you plan to retry
--   requests so that CloudFormation knows that you're not attempting to
--   delete a stack with the same name. You might retry
--   <tt>DeleteStack</tt> requests to ensure that CloudFormation
--   successfully received them.
--   
--   All events triggered by a given stack operation are assigned the same
--   client request token, which you can use to track operations. For
--   example, if you execute a <tt>CreateStack</tt> operation with the
--   token <tt>token1</tt>, then all the <tt>StackEvents</tt> generated by
--   that operation will have <tt>ClientRequestToken</tt> set as
--   <tt>token1</tt>.
--   
--   In the console, stack operations display the client request token on
--   the Events tab. Stack operations that are initiated from the console
--   use the token format <i>Console-StackOperation-ID</i>, which helps you
--   easily identify the stack operation . For example, if you create a
--   stack using the console, each stack event would be assigned the same
--   token in the following format:
--   <tt>Console-CreateStack-7f59c3cf-00d2-40c7-b2ff-e75db0987002</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:stackName:DeleteStack'</a>, <a>deleteStack_stackName</a> - The
--   name or the unique stack ID that is associated with the stack.
newDeleteStack :: Text -> DeleteStack

-- | The input for an UpdateStack action.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newUpdateStack</a> smart constructor.
data UpdateStack
UpdateStack' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [Capability] -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [Tag] -> Maybe RollbackConfiguration -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe [Parameter] -> Maybe Bool -> Text -> UpdateStack

-- | Create a value of <a>UpdateStack</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:stackPolicyDuringUpdateBody:UpdateStack'</a>,
--   <a>updateStack_stackPolicyDuringUpdateBody</a> - Structure containing
--   the temporary overriding stack policy body. You can specify either the
--   <tt>StackPolicyDuringUpdateBody</tt> or the
--   <tt>StackPolicyDuringUpdateURL</tt> parameter, but not both.
--   
--   If you want to update protected resources, specify a temporary
--   overriding stack policy during this update. If you do not specify a
--   stack policy, the current policy that is associated with the stack
--   will be used.
--   
--   <a>$sel:roleARN:UpdateStack'</a>, <a>updateStack_roleARN</a> - The
--   Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of an Identity and Access Management (IAM)
--   role that CloudFormation assumes to update the stack. CloudFormation
--   uses the role's credentials to make calls on your behalf.
--   CloudFormation always uses this role for all future operations on the
--   stack. As long as users have permission to operate on the stack,
--   CloudFormation uses this role even if the users don't have permission
--   to pass it. Ensure that the role grants least privilege.
--   
--   If you don't specify a value, CloudFormation uses the role that was
--   previously associated with the stack. If no role is available,
--   CloudFormation uses a temporary session that is generated from your
--   user credentials.
--   
--   <a>$sel:resourceTypes:UpdateStack'</a>,
--   <a>updateStack_resourceTypes</a> - The template resource types that
--   you have permissions to work with for this update stack action, such
--   as <tt>AWS::EC2::Instance</tt>, <tt>AWS::EC2::*</tt>, or
--   <tt>Custom::MyCustomInstance</tt>.
--   
--   If the list of resource types doesn't include a resource that you're
--   updating, the stack update fails. By default, CloudFormation grants
--   permissions to all resource types. Identity and Access Management
--   (IAM) uses this parameter for CloudFormation-specific condition keys
--   in IAM policies. For more information, see <a>Controlling Access with
--   Identity and Access Management</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:stackPolicyBody:UpdateStack'</a>,
--   <a>updateStack_stackPolicyBody</a> - Structure containing a new stack
--   policy body. You can specify either the <tt>StackPolicyBody</tt> or
--   the <tt>StackPolicyURL</tt> parameter, but not both.
--   
--   You might update the stack policy, for example, in order to protect a
--   new resource that you created during a stack update. If you do not
--   specify a stack policy, the current policy that is associated with the
--   stack is unchanged.
--   
--   <a>$sel:capabilities:UpdateStack'</a>, <a>updateStack_capabilities</a>
--   - In some cases, you must explicitly acknowledge that your stack
--   template contains certain capabilities in order for CloudFormation to
--   update the stack.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>CAPABILITY_IAM</tt> and <tt>CAPABILITY_NAMED_IAM</tt>Some
--   stack templates might include resources that can affect permissions in
--   your Amazon Web Services account; for example, by creating new
--   Identity and Access Management (IAM) users. For those stacks, you must
--   explicitly acknowledge this by specifying one of these
--   capabilities.The following IAM resources require you to specify either
--   the <tt>CAPABILITY_IAM</tt> or <tt>CAPABILITY_NAMED_IAM</tt>
--   capability.<ul><li>If you have IAM resources, you can specify either
--   capability.</li><li>If you have IAM resources with custom names, you
--   <i>must</i> specify <tt>CAPABILITY_NAMED_IAM</tt>.</li><li>If you
--   don't specify either of these capabilities, CloudFormation returns an
--   <tt>InsufficientCapabilities</tt> error.</li></ul>If your stack
--   template contains these resources, we recommend that you review all
--   permissions associated with them and edit their permissions if
--   necessary.<ul><li><a>AWS::IAM::AccessKey</a></li><li><a>AWS::IAM::Group</a></li><li><a>AWS::IAM::InstanceProfile</a></li><li><a>AWS::IAM::Policy</a></li><li><a>AWS::IAM::Role</a></li><li><a>AWS::IAM::User</a></li><li><a>AWS::IAM::UserToGroupAddition</a></li></ul>For
--   more information, see <a>Acknowledging IAM Resources in CloudFormation
--   Templates</a>.</li>
--   <li><pre>CAPABILITY_AUTO_EXPAND</pre>Some template contain macros.
--   Macros perform custom processing on templates; this can include simple
--   actions like find-and-replace operations, all the way to extensive
--   transformations of entire templates. Because of this, users typically
--   create a change set from the processed template, so that they can
--   review the changes resulting from the macros before actually updating
--   the stack. If your stack template contains one or more macros, and you
--   choose to update a stack directly from the processed template, without
--   first reviewing the resulting changes in a change set, you must
--   acknowledge this capability. This includes the <a>AWS::Include</a> and
--   <a>AWS::Serverless</a> transforms, which are macros hosted by
--   CloudFormation.If you want to update a stack from a stack template
--   that contains macros <i>and</i> nested stacks, you must update the
--   stack directly from the template using this capability.You should only
--   update stacks directly from a stack template that contains macros if
--   you know what processing the macro performs.Each macro relies on an
--   underlying Lambda service function for processing stack templates. Be
--   aware that the Lambda function owner can update the function operation
--   without CloudFormation being notified.For more information, see
--   <a>Using CloudFormation Macros to Perform Custom Processing on
--   Templates</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:notificationARNs:UpdateStack'</a>,
--   <a>updateStack_notificationARNs</a> - Amazon Simple Notification
--   Service topic Amazon Resource Names (ARNs) that CloudFormation
--   associates with the stack. Specify an empty list to remove all
--   notification topics.
--   
--   <a>$sel:templateURL:UpdateStack'</a>, <a>updateStack_templateURL</a> -
--   Location of file containing the template body. The URL must point to a
--   template that is located in an Amazon S3 bucket or a Systems Manager
--   document. For more information, go to <a>Template Anatomy</a> in the
--   CloudFormation User Guide.
--   
--   Conditional: You must specify only one of the following parameters:
--   <tt>TemplateBody</tt>, <tt>TemplateURL</tt>, or set the
--   <tt>UsePreviousTemplate</tt> to <tt>true</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:stackPolicyURL:UpdateStack'</a>,
--   <a>updateStack_stackPolicyURL</a> - Location of a file containing the
--   updated stack policy. The URL must point to a policy (max size: 16KB)
--   located in an S3 bucket in the same Region as the stack. You can
--   specify either the <tt>StackPolicyBody</tt> or the
--   <tt>StackPolicyURL</tt> parameter, but not both.
--   
--   You might update the stack policy, for example, in order to protect a
--   new resource that you created during a stack update. If you do not
--   specify a stack policy, the current policy that is associated with the
--   stack is unchanged.
--   
--   <a>$sel:stackPolicyDuringUpdateURL:UpdateStack'</a>,
--   <a>updateStack_stackPolicyDuringUpdateURL</a> - Location of a file
--   containing the temporary overriding stack policy. The URL must point
--   to a policy (max size: 16KB) located in an S3 bucket in the same
--   Region as the stack. You can specify either the
--   <tt>StackPolicyDuringUpdateBody</tt> or the
--   <tt>StackPolicyDuringUpdateURL</tt> parameter, but not both.
--   
--   If you want to update protected resources, specify a temporary
--   overriding stack policy during this update. If you do not specify a
--   stack policy, the current policy that is associated with the stack
--   will be used.
--   
--   <a>$sel:tags:UpdateStack'</a>, <a>updateStack_tags</a> - Key-value
--   pairs to associate with this stack. CloudFormation also propagates
--   these tags to supported resources in the stack. You can specify a
--   maximum number of 50 tags.
--   
--   If you don't specify this parameter, CloudFormation doesn't modify the
--   stack's tags. If you specify an empty value, CloudFormation removes
--   all associated tags.
--   
--   <a>$sel:rollbackConfiguration:UpdateStack'</a>,
--   <a>updateStack_rollbackConfiguration</a> - The rollback triggers for
--   CloudFormation to monitor during stack creation and updating
--   operations, and for the specified monitoring period afterwards.
--   
--   <a>$sel:clientRequestToken:UpdateStack'</a>,
--   <a>updateStack_clientRequestToken</a> - A unique identifier for this
--   <tt>UpdateStack</tt> request. Specify this token if you plan to retry
--   requests so that CloudFormation knows that you're not attempting to
--   update a stack with the same name. You might retry
--   <tt>UpdateStack</tt> requests to ensure that CloudFormation
--   successfully received them.
--   
--   All events triggered by a given stack operation are assigned the same
--   client request token, which you can use to track operations. For
--   example, if you execute a <tt>CreateStack</tt> operation with the
--   token <tt>token1</tt>, then all the <tt>StackEvents</tt> generated by
--   that operation will have <tt>ClientRequestToken</tt> set as
--   <tt>token1</tt>.
--   
--   In the console, stack operations display the client request token on
--   the Events tab. Stack operations that are initiated from the console
--   use the token format <i>Console-StackOperation-ID</i>, which helps you
--   easily identify the stack operation . For example, if you create a
--   stack using the console, each stack event would be assigned the same
--   token in the following format:
--   <tt>Console-CreateStack-7f59c3cf-00d2-40c7-b2ff-e75db0987002</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:templateBody:UpdateStack'</a>, <a>updateStack_templateBody</a>
--   - Structure containing the template body with a minimum length of 1
--   byte and a maximum length of 51,200 bytes. (For more information, go
--   to <a>Template Anatomy</a> in the CloudFormation User Guide.)
--   
--   Conditional: You must specify only one of the following parameters:
--   <tt>TemplateBody</tt>, <tt>TemplateURL</tt>, or set the
--   <tt>UsePreviousTemplate</tt> to <tt>true</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:disableRollback:UpdateStack'</a>,
--   <a>updateStack_disableRollback</a> - Preserve the state of previously
--   provisioned resources when an operation fails.
--   
--   Default: <tt>False</tt>
--   
--   <a>$sel:parameters:UpdateStack'</a>, <a>updateStack_parameters</a> - A
--   list of <tt>Parameter</tt> structures that specify input parameters
--   for the stack. For more information, see the <a>Parameter</a> data
--   type.
--   
--   <a>$sel:usePreviousTemplate:UpdateStack'</a>,
--   <a>updateStack_usePreviousTemplate</a> - Reuse the existing template
--   that is associated with the stack that you are updating.
--   
--   Conditional: You must specify only one of the following parameters:
--   <tt>TemplateBody</tt>, <tt>TemplateURL</tt>, or set the
--   <tt>UsePreviousTemplate</tt> to <tt>true</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:stackName:UpdateStack'</a>, <a>updateStack_stackName</a> - The
--   name or unique stack ID of the stack to update.
newUpdateStack :: Text -> UpdateStack

-- | Create a value of <a>SignalResource</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:stackName:SignalResource'</a>, <a>signalResource_stackName</a>
--   - The stack name or unique stack ID that includes the resource that
--   you want to signal.
--   
--   <a>$sel:logicalResourceId:SignalResource'</a>,
--   <a>signalResource_logicalResourceId</a> - The logical ID of the
--   resource that you want to signal. The logical ID is the name of the
--   resource that given in the template.
--   
--   <a>$sel:uniqueId:SignalResource'</a>, <a>signalResource_uniqueId</a> -
--   A unique ID of the signal. When you signal Amazon EC2 instances or
--   Auto Scaling groups, specify the instance ID that you are signaling as
--   the unique ID. If you send multiple signals to a single resource (such
--   as signaling a wait condition), each signal requires a different
--   unique ID.
--   
--   <a>$sel:status:SignalResource'</a>, <a>signalResource_status</a> - The
--   status of the signal, which is either success or failure. A failure
--   signal causes CloudFormation to immediately fail the stack creation or
--   update.
newSignalResource :: Text -> Text -> Text -> ResourceSignalStatus -> SignalResource

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newSignalResourceResponse</a> smart constructor.

-- | Create a value of <a>SignalResourceResponse</a> with all optional

-- | Create a value of <a>ListTypes</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:nextToken:ListTypes'</a>, <a>listTypes_nextToken</a> - If the
--   previous paginated request didn't return all of the remaining results,
--   the response object's <tt>NextToken</tt> parameter value is set to a
--   token. To retrieve the next set of results, call this action again and
--   assign that token to the request object's <tt>NextToken</tt>
--   parameter. If there are no remaining results, the previous response
--   object's <tt>NextToken</tt> parameter is set to <tt>null</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:maxResults:ListTypes'</a>, <a>listTypes_maxResults</a> - The
--   maximum number of results to be returned with a single call. If the
--   number of available results exceeds this maximum, the response
--   includes a <tt>NextToken</tt> value that you can assign to the
--   <tt>NextToken</tt> request parameter to get the next set of results.
--   
--   <a>$sel:deprecatedStatus:ListTypes'</a>,
--   <a>listTypes_deprecatedStatus</a> - The deprecation status of the
--   extension that you want to get summary information about.
--   
--   Valid values include:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>LIVE</tt>: The extension is registered for use in
--   CloudFormation operations.</li>
--   <li><tt>DEPRECATED</tt>: The extension has been deregistered and can
--   no longer be used in CloudFormation operations.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:provisioningType:ListTypes'</a>,
--   <a>listTypes_provisioningType</a> - For resource types, the
--   provisioning behavior of the resource type. CloudFormation determines
--   the provisioning type during registration, based on the types of
--   handlers in the schema handler package submitted.
--   
--   Valid values include:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>FULLY_MUTABLE</tt>: The resource type includes an update
--   handler to process updates to the type during stack update
--   operations.</li>
--   <li><tt>IMMUTABLE</tt>: The resource type does not include an update
--   handler, so the type cannot be updated and must instead be replaced
--   during stack update operations.</li>
--   <li><tt>NON_PROVISIONABLE</tt>: The resource type does not include
--   create, read, and delete handlers, and therefore cannot actually be
--   provisioned.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   The default is <tt>FULLY_MUTABLE</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:visibility:ListTypes'</a>, <a>listTypes_visibility</a> - The
--   scope at which the extensions are visible and usable in CloudFormation
--   operations.
--   
--   Valid values include:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>PRIVATE</tt>: Extensions that are visible and usable within
--   this account and region. This includes:<ul><li>Private extensions you
--   have registered in this account and region.</li><li>Public extensions
--   that you have activated in this account and region.</li></ul></li>
--   <li><tt>PUBLIC</tt>: Extensions that are publicly visible and
--   available to be activated within any Amazon account. This includes
--   extensions from Amazon, as well as third-party publishers.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   The default is <tt>PRIVATE</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:filters:ListTypes'</a>, <a>listTypes_filters</a> - Filter
--   criteria to use in determining which extensions to return.
--   
--   If you specify a filter, CloudFormation ignores any specified
--   <tt>Visibility</tt> value when returning the list of types.
--   
--   <a>$sel:type':ListTypes'</a>, <a>listTypes_type</a> - The type of
--   extension.
newListTypes :: ListTypes

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newRegisterType</a> smart constructor.
data RegisterType
RegisterType' :: Maybe LoggingConfig -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe RegistryType -> Text -> Text -> RegisterType

-- | Create a value of <a>RegisterType</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:loggingConfig:RegisterType'</a>,
--   <a>registerType_loggingConfig</a> - Specifies logging configuration
--   information for an extension.
--   
--   <a>$sel:executionRoleArn:RegisterType'</a>,
--   <a>registerType_executionRoleArn</a> - The Amazon Resource Name (ARN)
--   of the IAM role for CloudFormation to assume when invoking the
--   extension.
--   
--   For CloudFormation to assume the specified execution role, the role
--   must contain a trust relationship with the CloudFormation service
--   principle (<tt>resources.cloudformation.amazonaws.com</tt>). For more
--   information on adding trust relationships, see <a>Modifying a role
--   trust policy</a> in the <i>Identity and Access Management User
--   Guide</i>.
--   
--   If your extension calls Amazon Web Services APIs in any of its
--   handlers, you must create an
--   <i>&lt;https:</i><i>docs.aws.amazon.com</i>IAM<i>latest</i>UserGuide<i>id_roles.html
--   IAM execution role&gt;</i> that includes the necessary permissions to
--   call those Amazon Web Services APIs, and provision that execution role
--   in your account. When CloudFormation needs to invoke the resource type
--   handler, CloudFormation assumes this execution role to create a
--   temporary session token, which it then passes to the resource type
--   handler, thereby supplying your resource type with the appropriate
--   credentials.
--   
--   <a>$sel:clientRequestToken:RegisterType'</a>,
--   <a>registerType_clientRequestToken</a> - A unique identifier that acts
--   as an idempotency key for this registration request. Specifying a
--   client request token prevents CloudFormation from generating more than
--   one version of an extension from the same registeration request, even
--   if the request is submitted multiple times.
--   
--   <a>$sel:type':RegisterType'</a>, <a>registerType_type</a> - The kind
--   of extension.
--   
--   <a>$sel:typeName:RegisterType'</a>, <a>registerType_typeName</a> - The
--   name of the extension being registered.
--   
--   We recommend that extension names adhere to the following patterns:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>For resource types,
--   <i>company_or_organization</i>::<i>service</i>::<i>type</i>.</li>
--   <li>For modules,
--   <i>company_or_organization</i>::<i>service</i>::<i>type</i>::MODULE.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   The following organization namespaces are reserved and cannot be used
--   in your extension names:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><pre>Alexa</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>AMZN</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Amazon</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>AWS</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Custom</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Dev</pre></li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:schemaHandlerPackage:RegisterType'</a>,
--   <a>registerType_schemaHandlerPackage</a> - A url to the S3 bucket
--   containing the extension project package that contains the neccessary
--   files for the extension you want to register.
--   
--   For information on generating a schema handler package for the
--   extension you want to register, see <a>submit</a> in the
--   <i>CloudFormation CLI User Guide</i>.
--   
--   The user registering the extension must be able to access the package
--   in the S3 bucket. That is, the user needs to have <a>GetObject</a>
--   permissions for the schema handler package. For more information, see
--   <a>Actions, Resources, and Condition Keys for Amazon S3</a> in the
--   <i>Identity and Access Management User Guide</i>.
newRegisterType :: Text -> Text -> RegisterType

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newRegisterTypeResponse</a> smart constructor.

--   <tt>Type</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:arn:PublishType'</a>, <a>publishType_arn</a> - The Amazon
--   Resource Number (ARN) of the extension.
--   
--   Conditional: You must specify <tt>Arn</tt>, or <tt>TypeName</tt> and
--   <tt>Type</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:publicVersionNumber:PublishType'</a>,
--   <a>publishType_publicVersionNumber</a> - The version number to assign
--   to this version of the extension.
--   
--   Use the following format, and adhere to semantic versioning when
--   assigning a version number to your extension:
--   
--   <pre>
--   MAJOR.MINOR.PATCH
--   </pre>
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Semantic Versioning 2.0.0</a>.
--   
--   If you do not specify a version number, CloudFormation increments the
--   version number by one minor version release.
--   
--   The first time you publish a type, CloudFormation sets the version
--   number to <tt>1.0.0</tt>, regardless of the value you specify.
--   
--   <a>$sel:type':PublishType'</a>, <a>publishType_type</a> - The type of
--   the extension.
--   
--   Conditional: You must specify <tt>Arn</tt>, or <tt>TypeName</tt> and
--   <tt>Type</tt>.

ActivateType' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe LoggingConfig -> Maybe Natural -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe VersionBump -> Maybe ThirdPartyType -> ActivateType

-- | Create a value of <a>ActivateType</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:typeName:ActivateType'</a>, <a>activateType_typeName</a> - The
--   name of the extension.
--   
--   Conditional: You must specify <tt>PublicTypeArn</tt>, or
--   <tt>TypeName</tt>, <tt>Type</tt>, and <tt>PublisherId</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:publicTypeArn:ActivateType'</a>,
--   <a>activateType_publicTypeArn</a> - The Amazon Resource Number (ARN)
--   of the public extension.
--   
--   Conditional: You must specify <tt>PublicTypeArn</tt>, or
--   <tt>TypeName</tt>, <tt>Type</tt>, and <tt>PublisherId</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:loggingConfig:ActivateType'</a>,
--   <a>activateType_loggingConfig</a> - Undocumented member.
--   
--   <a>$sel:majorVersion:ActivateType'</a>,
--   <a>activateType_majorVersion</a> - The major version of this extension
--   you want to activate, if multiple major versions are available. The
--   default is the latest major version. CloudFormation uses the latest
--   available <i>minor</i> version of the major version selected.
--   
--   You can specify <tt>MajorVersion</tt> or <tt>VersionBump</tt>, but not
--   both.
--   
--   <a>$sel:publisherId:ActivateType'</a>, <a>activateType_publisherId</a>
--   - The ID of the extension publisher.
--   
--   Conditional: You must specify <tt>PublicTypeArn</tt>, or
--   <tt>TypeName</tt>, <tt>Type</tt>, and <tt>PublisherId</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:executionRoleArn:ActivateType'</a>,
--   <a>activateType_executionRoleArn</a> - The name of the IAM execution
--   role to use to activate the extension.
--   
--   <a>$sel:typeNameAlias:ActivateType'</a>,
--   <a>activateType_typeNameAlias</a> - An alias to assign to the public
--   extension, in this account and region. If you specify an alias for the
--   extension, CloudFormation treats the alias as the extension type name
--   within this account and region. You must use the alias to refer to the
--   extension in your templates, API calls, and CloudFormation console.
--   
--   An extension alias must be unique within a given account and region.
--   You can activate the same public resource multiple times in the same
--   account and region, using different type name aliases.
--   
--   <a>$sel:autoUpdate:ActivateType'</a>, <a>activateType_autoUpdate</a> -
--   Whether to automatically update the extension in this account and
--   region when a new <i>minor</i> version is published by the extension
--   publisher. Major versions released by the publisher must be manually
--   updated.
--   
--   The default is <tt>true</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:versionBump:ActivateType'</a>, <a>activateType_versionBump</a>
--   - Manually updates a previously-activated type to a new major or minor
--   version, if available. You can also use this parameter to update the
--   value of <tt>AutoUpdate</tt>.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>MAJOR</tt>: CloudFormation updates the extension to the newest
--   major version, if one is available.</li>
--   <li><tt>MINOR</tt>: CloudFormation updates the extension to the newest
--   minor version, if one is available.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:type':ActivateType'</a>, <a>activateType_type</a> - The
--   extension type.
--   
--   Conditional: You must specify <tt>PublicTypeArn</tt>, or
--   <tt>TypeName</tt>, <tt>Type</tt>, and <tt>PublisherId</tt>.
newActivateType :: ActivateType

data GetTemplate

-- | Create a value of <a>GetTemplate</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.

--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:templateStage:GetTemplate'</a>,
--   <a>getTemplate_templateStage</a> - For templates that include
--   transforms, the stage of the template that CloudFormation returns. To
--   get the user-submitted template, specify <tt>Original</tt>. To get the
--   template after CloudFormation has processed all transforms, specify
--   <tt>Processed</tt>.
--   
--   If the template doesn't include transforms, <tt>Original</tt> and
--   <tt>Processed</tt> return the same template. By default,
--   CloudFormation specifies <tt>Processed</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:stackName:GetTemplate'</a>, <a>getTemplate_stackName</a> - The
--   name or the unique stack ID that is associated with the stack, which
--   are not always interchangeable:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Running stacks: You can specify either the stack's name or its
--   unique stack ID.</li>
--   <li>Deleted stacks: You must specify the unique stack ID.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   Default: There is no default value.
--   
--   <a>$sel:changeSetName:GetTemplate'</a>,
--   <a>getTemplate_changeSetName</a> - The name or Amazon Resource Name
--   (ARN) of a change set for which CloudFormation returns the associated
--   template. If you specify a name, you must also specify the
--   <tt>StackName</tt>.
newGetTemplate :: GetTemplate

--   <tt>Processed</tt> templates are always available. For change sets,
--   the <tt>Original</tt> template is always available. After

--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:roleARN:ContinueUpdateRollback'</a>,
--   <a>continueUpdateRollback_roleARN</a> - The Amazon Resource Name (ARN)
--   of an Identity and Access Management (IAM) role that CloudFormation
--   assumes to roll back the stack. CloudFormation uses the role's
--   credentials to make calls on your behalf. CloudFormation always uses
--   this role for all future operations on the stack. As long as users
--   have permission to operate on the stack, CloudFormation uses this role
--   even if the users don't have permission to pass it. Ensure that the
--   role grants least privilege.
--   
--   If you don't specify a value, CloudFormation uses the role that was
--   previously associated with the stack. If no role is available,
--   CloudFormation uses a temporary session that is generated from your
--   user credentials.
--   
--   <a>$sel:resourcesToSkip:ContinueUpdateRollback'</a>,
--   <a>continueUpdateRollback_resourcesToSkip</a> - A list of the logical
--   IDs of the resources that CloudFormation skips during the continue
--   update rollback operation. You can specify only resources that are in
--   the <tt>UPDATE_FAILED</tt> state because a rollback failed. You can't
--   specify resources that are in the <tt>UPDATE_FAILED</tt> state for
--   other reasons, for example, because an update was cancelled. To check
--   why a resource update failed, use the DescribeStackResources action,
--   and view the resource status reason.
--   
--   Specify this property to skip rolling back resources that
--   CloudFormation can't successfully roll back. We recommend that you
--   <a>troubleshoot</a> resources before skipping them. CloudFormation
--   sets the status of the specified resources to <tt>UPDATE_COMPLETE</tt>
--   and continues to roll back the stack. After the rollback is complete,
--   the state of the skipped resources will be inconsistent with the state
--   of the resources in the stack template. Before performing another
--   stack update, you must update the stack or resources to be consistent
--   with each other. If you don't, subsequent stack updates might fail,
--   and the stack will become unrecoverable.
--   
--   Specify the minimum number of resources required to successfully roll
--   back your stack. For example, a failed resource update might cause
--   dependent resources to fail. In this case, it might not be necessary
--   to skip the dependent resources.
--   
--   To skip resources that are part of nested stacks, use the following
--   format: <tt>NestedStackName.ResourceLogicalID</tt>. If you want to
--   specify the logical ID of a stack resource (<tt>Type:
--   AWS::CloudFormation::Stack</tt>) in the <tt>ResourcesToSkip</tt> list,
--   then its corresponding embedded stack must be in one of the following
--   states: <tt>DELETE_IN_PROGRESS</tt>, <tt>DELETE_COMPLETE</tt>, or
--   <tt>DELETE_FAILED</tt>.
--   
--   Don't confuse a child stack's name with its corresponding logical ID
--   defined in the parent stack. For an example of a continue update
--   rollback operation with nested stacks, see <a>Using ResourcesToSkip to
--   recover a nested stacks hierarchy</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:clientRequestToken:ContinueUpdateRollback'</a>,
--   <a>continueUpdateRollback_clientRequestToken</a> - A unique identifier
--   for this <tt>ContinueUpdateRollback</tt> request. Specify this token
--   if you plan to retry requests so that CloudFormationknows that you're
--   not attempting to continue the rollback to a stack with the same name.
--   You might retry <tt>ContinueUpdateRollback</tt> requests to ensure
--   that CloudFormation successfully received them.
--   
--   <a>$sel:stackName:ContinueUpdateRollback'</a>,
--   <a>continueUpdateRollback_stackName</a> - The name or the unique ID of
--   the stack that you want to continue rolling back.
--   
--   Don't specify the name of a nested stack (a stack that was created by
--   using the <tt>AWS::CloudFormation::Stack</tt> resource). Instead, use
--   this operation on the parent stack (the stack that contains the
--   <tt>AWS::CloudFormation::Stack</tt> resource).
newContinueUpdateRollback :: Text -> ContinueUpdateRollback

-- | The output for a ContinueUpdateRollback action.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newContinueUpdateRollbackResponse</a> smart

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newCreateStackSet</a> smart constructor.
data CreateStackSet
CreateStackSet' :: Maybe PermissionModels -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [Capability] -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe CallAs -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [Tag] -> Maybe AutoDeployment -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [Parameter] -> Text -> CreateStackSet

-- | Create a value of <a>CreateStackSet</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:permissionModel:CreateStackSet'</a>,
--   <a>createStackSet_permissionModel</a> - Describes how the IAM roles
--   required for stack set operations are created. By default,
--   <tt>SELF-MANAGED</tt> is specified.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>With <tt>self-managed</tt> permissions, you must create the
--   administrator and execution roles required to deploy to target
--   accounts. For more information, see <a>Grant Self-Managed Stack Set
--   Permissions</a>.</li>
--   <li>With <tt>service-managed</tt> permissions, StackSets automatically
--   creates the IAM roles required to deploy to accounts managed by
--   Organizations. For more information, see <a>Grant Service-Managed
--   Stack Set Permissions</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:executionRoleName:CreateStackSet'</a>,
--   <a>createStackSet_executionRoleName</a> - The name of the IAM
--   execution role to use to create the stack set. If you do not specify
--   an execution role, CloudFormation uses the
--   <tt>AWSCloudFormationStackSetExecutionRole</tt> role for the stack set
--   operation.
--   
--   Specify an IAM role only if you are using customized execution roles
--   to control which stack resources users and groups can include in their
--   stack sets.
--   
--   <a>$sel:capabilities:CreateStackSet'</a>,
--   <a>createStackSet_capabilities</a> - In some cases, you must
--   explicitly acknowledge that your stack set template contains certain
--   capabilities in order for CloudFormation to create the stack set and
--   related stack instances.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>CAPABILITY_IAM</tt> and <tt>CAPABILITY_NAMED_IAM</tt>Some
--   stack templates might include resources that can affect permissions in
--   your Amazon Web Services account; for example, by creating new
--   Identity and Access Management (IAM) users. For those stack sets, you
--   must explicitly acknowledge this by specifying one of these
--   capabilities.The following IAM resources require you to specify either
--   the <tt>CAPABILITY_IAM</tt> or <tt>CAPABILITY_NAMED_IAM</tt>
--   capability.<ul><li>If you have IAM resources, you can specify either
--   capability.</li><li>If you have IAM resources with custom names, you
--   <i>must</i> specify <tt>CAPABILITY_NAMED_IAM</tt>.</li><li>If you
--   don't specify either of these capabilities, CloudFormation returns an
--   <tt>InsufficientCapabilities</tt> error.</li></ul>If your stack
--   template contains these resources, we recommend that you review all
--   permissions associated with them and edit their permissions if
--   necessary.<ul><li><a>AWS::IAM::AccessKey</a></li><li><a>AWS::IAM::Group</a></li><li><a>AWS::IAM::InstanceProfile</a></li><li><a>AWS::IAM::Policy</a></li><li><a>AWS::IAM::Role</a></li><li><a>AWS::IAM::User</a></li><li><a>AWS::IAM::UserToGroupAddition</a></li></ul>For
--   more information, see <a>Acknowledging IAM Resources in CloudFormation
--   Templates</a>.</li>
--   <li><pre>CAPABILITY_AUTO_EXPAND</pre>Some templates reference macros.
--   If your stack set template references one or more macros, you must
--   create the stack set directly from the processed template, without
--   first reviewing the resulting changes in a change set. To create the
--   stack set directly, you must acknowledge this capability. For more
--   information, see <a>Using CloudFormation Macros to Perform Custom
--   Processing on Templates</a>.Stack sets with service-managed
--   permissions do not currently support the use of macros in templates.
--   (This includes the <a>AWS::Include</a> and <a>AWS::Serverless</a>
--   transforms, which are macros hosted by CloudFormation.) Even if you
--   specify this capability for a stack set with service-managed
--   permissions, if you reference a macro in your template the stack set
--   operation will fail.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:stackId:CreateStackSet'</a>, <a>createStackSet_stackId</a> -
--   The stack ID you are importing into a new stack set. Specify the
--   Amazon Resource Number (ARN) of the stack.
--   
--   <a>$sel:templateURL:CreateStackSet'</a>,
--   <a>createStackSet_templateURL</a> - The location of the file that
--   contains the template body. The URL must point to a template (maximum
--   size: 460,800 bytes) that's located in an Amazon S3 bucket or a
--   Systems Manager document. For more information, see <a>Template
--   Anatomy</a> in the CloudFormation User Guide.
--   
--   Conditional: You must specify either the TemplateBody or the
--   TemplateURL parameter, but not both.
--   
--   <a>$sel:callAs:CreateStackSet'</a>, <a>createStackSet_callAs</a> -
--   [Service-managed permissions] Specifies whether you are acting as an
--   account administrator in the organization's management account or as a
--   delegated administrator in a member account.
--   
--   By default, <tt>SELF</tt> is specified. Use <tt>SELF</tt> for stack
--   sets with self-managed permissions.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>To create a stack set with service-managed permissions while
--   signed in to the management account, specify <tt>SELF</tt>.</li>
--   <li>To create a stack set with service-managed permissions while
--   signed in to a delegated administrator account, specify
--   <tt>DELEGATED_ADMIN</tt>.Your Amazon Web Services account must be
--   registered as a delegated admin in the management account. For more
--   information, see <a>Register a delegated administrator</a> in the
--   <i>CloudFormation User Guide</i>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   Stack sets with service-managed permissions are created in the
--   management account, including stack sets that are created by delegated
--   administrators.
--   
--   <a>$sel:administrationRoleARN:CreateStackSet'</a>,
--   <a>createStackSet_administrationRoleARN</a> - The Amazon Resource
--   Number (ARN) of the IAM role to use to create this stack set.
--   
--   Specify an IAM role only if you are using customized administrator
--   roles to control which users or groups can manage specific stack sets
--   within the same administrator account. For more information, see
--   <a>Prerequisites: Granting Permissions for Stack Set Operations</a> in
--   the <i>CloudFormation User Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:tags:CreateStackSet'</a>, <a>createStackSet_tags</a> - The
--   key-value pairs to associate with this stack set and the stacks
--   created from it. CloudFormation also propagates these tags to
--   supported resources that are created in the stacks. A maximum number
--   of 50 tags can be specified.
--   
--   If you specify tags as part of a <tt>CreateStackSet</tt> action,
--   CloudFormation checks to see if you have the required IAM permission
--   to tag resources. If you don't, the entire <tt>CreateStackSet</tt>
--   action fails with an <tt>access denied</tt> error, and the stack set
--   is not created.
--   
--   <a>$sel:autoDeployment:CreateStackSet'</a>,
--   <a>createStackSet_autoDeployment</a> - Describes whether StackSets
--   automatically deploys to Organizations accounts that are added to the
--   target organization or organizational unit (OU). Specify only if
--   <tt>PermissionModel</tt> is <tt>SERVICE_MANAGED</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:description:CreateStackSet'</a>,
--   <a>createStackSet_description</a> - A description of the stack set.
--   You can use the description to identify the stack set's purpose or
--   other important information.
--   
--   <a>$sel:clientRequestToken:CreateStackSet'</a>,
--   <a>createStackSet_clientRequestToken</a> - A unique identifier for
--   this <tt>CreateStackSet</tt> request. Specify this token if you plan
--   to retry requests so that CloudFormation knows that you're not
--   attempting to create another stack set with the same name. You might
--   retry <tt>CreateStackSet</tt> requests to ensure that CloudFormation
--   successfully received them.
--   
--   If you don't specify an operation ID, the SDK generates one
--   automatically.
--   
--   <a>$sel:templateBody:CreateStackSet'</a>,
--   <a>createStackSet_templateBody</a> - The structure that contains the
--   template body, with a minimum length of 1 byte and a maximum length of
--   51,200 bytes. For more information, see <a>Template Anatomy</a> in the
--   CloudFormation User Guide.
--   
--   Conditional: You must specify either the TemplateBody or the
--   TemplateURL parameter, but not both.
--   
--   <a>$sel:parameters:CreateStackSet'</a>,
--   <a>createStackSet_parameters</a> - The input parameters for the stack
--   set template.
--   
--   <a>$sel:stackSetName:CreateStackSet'</a>,
--   <a>createStackSet_stackSetName</a> - The name to associate with the
--   stack set. The name must be unique in the Region where you create your
--   stack set.
--   
--   A stack name can contain only alphanumeric characters (case-sensitive)
--   and hyphens. It must start with an alphabetic character and can't be
--   longer than 128 characters.
newCreateStackSet :: Text -> CreateStackSet
